{{Distinguish | José Báez (baseball) | José Luis Báez }} {{Infobox person |name = Jose Baez |image = | image_size = 250 |birth_name =Jose Angel Baez |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1970|9|17}} |birth_place = [[Manhattan, New York]]{{cite web|title=Barbara Walters interview with Jose Baez July 5, 2011|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PlSRTtpaeMU|website=Youtube|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=17 July 2015}} |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |known_for = Lead attorney for [[Death of Caylee Anthony|Casey Anthony]] and [[Aaron Hernandez]] |education = [[Miami Dade College]]
[[Florida State University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[St. Thomas University School of Law]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |occupation = Trial attorney |website = {{URL|http://www.baezlawfirm.com}} }} '''Jose Angel Baez''' (born October 17, 1968) is an attorney and author.''Presumed Guilty: Casey Anthony: The Inside Story''. Jose Baez and Peter Golenbock. (2012) {{ISBN|978-1937856380}} He was the [[Defense attorney|lead attorney]] for [[Death of Caylee Anthony|Casey Anthony]], who was acquitted of murder in July 2011 after a trial that attracted national and international attention. Baez authored a book with [[Peter Golenbock]] about the case, ''Presumed Guilty'', which became a [[New York Times Best Seller]]. ==Early life and education== Baez was born to [[Puerto Ricans|Puerto Rican]] parents in Manhattan, N.Y., and raised in [[the Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]], and [[South Florida]] with his three sisters by his single mother.{{cite news| author = Carolyn Salazar| title =José Baez, Casey Anthony's Lawyer: From Troubled Son to Star Defense Attorney| quote = Baez was born in Puerto Rico and grew up in Bronx, N.Y., and South Florida with his single mother. He dropped out of school in the ninth grade. At 17, he married and became a father. | newspaper =[[Fox News]] Latino| date =July 5, 2011| url =http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2011/07/05/jose-baez-casey-anthonys-lawyer-from-troubled-son-to-star-defense-attorney/| accessdate =May 10, 2015}}[http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey_anthony_trial/casey-anthonys-lawyer-jose-baez-unknown-juannie-cochran/story?id=14002387 Video Interview 5 July 2011 with Barbara Walters], ABC ''[[Nightline]]'' News. By Nikki Battiste and Kimberly Brown, July 6, 2011. During the 2nd segment at video index 03:09, Baez says he was born in Manhattan. Other sources reported his place of birth as Puerto Rico, such as: * [http://www.wsvn.com/news/articles/local/21004765863776/ ''Profile: Jose Baez''] from ''[[WSVN]]'' 6 July 2011 * [http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/07/05/2301017_p2/jose-baez-casey-anthonys-lawyer.html ''Casey Anthony’s lawyer Jose Baez came out of nowhere''] from the ''[[Miami Herald]]'' 5 July 2011 He attended [[Homestead High School (Homestead, Florida)|Homestead High School]] in Florida, but dropped out in the ninth grade. He married and became a father at age 17. After earning his [[General Equivalency Diploma]] (GED), he joined the [[U.S. Navy]] in 1986. According to his resume, he spent three years assigned in connection with [[NATO]] at [[Norfolk, Virginia]], trained as an intelligence analyst, and held a Top Secret [[security clearance]].[http://en.terra.com/latin-in-america/news/exclusive_interview_with_casey_anthonys_lawyer_jose_baez/hof15569 "Exclusive Casey Anthony Lawyer Jose Baez Interview"], ''Terra'', June 22, 2020 . After leaving the Navy in 1989, Baez attended [[Miami-Dade Community College]], then transferred to [[Florida State University]] where he earned a BA. He earned his [[Juris Doctor]] degree from [[St. Thomas University School of Law]] in 1997.{{cite news| author = Carolyn Salazar| title =José Baez, Casey Anthony's Lawyer: From Troubled Son to Star Defense Attorney| quote =| newspaper =[[Fox News]] Latino| date =July 5, 2011| url =http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2011/07/05/jose-baez-casey-anthonys-lawyer-from-troubled-son-to-star-defense-attorney/| accessdate =May 10, 2015}} ==Career== After graduating from law school in 1997, Baez was denied admission to the Florida Bar due to financial irresponsibility.{{cite news|last=Hopper|first=Jessica|title=Casey Anthony's Lawyer Jose Baez Has Trials of His Own|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey-anthony-trial-defense-attorney-jose-baez/story?id=13784113#.UEZWlI1mR4c|date=8 June 2011}}{{cite web|last=Curtis|first=Henry P.|title=Casey Anthony's lawyer, Jose Baez, rejected by Florida Bar on first try|url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/may/03/casey-anthonys-lawyer-jose-baez-rejected-florida-b/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205012212/http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2009/may/03/casey-anthonys-lawyer-jose-baez-rejected-florida-b/|archivedate=5 December 2013|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=30 July 2017}} Unable to practice as an attorney, he worked instead as an intern at the Miami Dade Public Defender's office and owned several companies. In 2005, the Florida Board of Bar Examiners admitted Baez after he had demonstrated that he had rehabilitated himself. ===Criminal cases=== After being granted his license, he focused primarily on criminal defense cases, including the case of Elvira Garcia, an undocumented Mexican immigrant accused of kidnapping a child that she had adopted as her own. Garcia's charges were dropped, as it turned out to be more of a civil custody matter.{{cite web|url=http://www.wftv.com/news/news/roommate-charged-with-kidnapping-6-week-old-boy/nJsdr/ |title=Roommate Charged With Kidnapping 6-Week-Old Boy |publisher=www.wftv.com |date=2006-09-27 |accessdate=2013-06-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/casey-anthony-extended-coverage/Who-Is-Jose-Baez/-/13479888/13176420/-/item/0/-/fj5899/-/index.html |title=Who Is Jose Baez? | Casey Anthony – WESH Home |publisher=Wesh.com |date=2008-08-04 |accessdate=2013-06-18}} He also tried the first-degree murder case of Nilton Diaz, heavily covered by the media in Orlando and Puerto Rico because the victim was the 2-year-old granddaughter of World Boxing Champion [[Wilfredo Vazquez]].{{cite web|last=Hudak|first=Stephen|title=Nilton Diaz denies killing girl, 2, in Lake County murder trial|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-04-29/news/ldiaz29_1_diaz-tavares-child|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=17 February 2013}} Diaz was acquitted of first and second degree murder but convicted of manslaughter and child abuse. Baez came to significant national attention when he took on the [[Death of Caylee Anthony|case of Casey Anthony]]. Time Magazine dubbed it "the Social Media Trial of the Century".{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2077969,00.html|title=Casey Anthony Murder Case: Social-Media Trial of Century – TIME|publisher=content.time.com|accessdate=2014-03-22|date=2011-06-16}} Anthony was acquitted of the murder of her daughter, Caylee, after a trial that lasted six weeks. In a press conference on the day of the verdict, Baez said, "While we're happy for Casey, there are no winners in this case. Caylee has passed on far, far too soon, and what my driving force has been for the last three years has been always to make sure that there has been justice for Caylee and Casey because Casey did not murder Caylee. It's that simple." He added, "And today our system of justice has not dishonored her memory by a false conviction."{{cite news|first=Kyle|last=Hightower|title=Jurors see scant evidence in Casey Anthony trial|publisher=MSNBC/''Associated Press''|date=July 2, 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43617797/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/jurors-see-scant-evidence-casey-anthony-trial/}} Baez was featured on every major news network and show across the country. Baez authored a book with [[Peter Golenbock]] about the Anthony Case, ''Presumed Guilty'', which was published on July 3, 2012 and became a [[New York Times Best Seller]]. [[Fox News Channel]] commentator [[Geraldo Rivera]] referred to Baez as "Juanie Cochran."{{cite news|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2011/06/02/geraldo-rivera-juanie-cochran-casey-anthony/ |title=Geraldo Rivera: Juanie Cochran | Fox News Latino |publisher=Latino.foxnews.com |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2013-06-18}} ===Missing in Aruba=== After representing Anthony, Baez was brought on to assist attorney Chris Lejuez in representing millionaire businessman Gary Giordano in [[Aruba]]. Giordano was detained in KIA Prison for 116 days in connection with the disappearance of Robyn Gardner.http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/gary-giordano-hires-casey-anthonys-lawyer-14689376 * http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/14/gary-giordano-troubled-past_n_926421.html Aruba's High Court released Gary Giordano on November 28, 2011. No charges were ever filed against Gary Giordano. Baez and Lejuez successfully defended an appeal filed by Aruba's Chief Prosecutor, Taco Stein.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/45496675/#.UqjmlM1A_v4|title=Freed US man wins Aruba appeal – US news – Crime & courts | NBC News|publisher=nbcnews.com|accessdate=2014-03-22}} Baez defended Giordano on the American [[reality television|reality]] prime time [[court show]] ''[[You the Jury]]'', which was canceled after two episodes. Baez also defended Gerod Roth in the show. ===George Zimmerman case=== In 2012, [[George Zimmerman]] was arrested in the [[Shooting of Trayvon Martin|shooting death of 17‑year‑old Trayvon Martin]]. After jail calls that were released where George Zimmerman discussed Baez, Zimmerman's friend Frank Taaffe disclosed to [[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]] that a "consortium" wanted to hire Baez to represent George Zimmerman.{{cite web|url=http://www.hlntv.com/article/2012/07/20/consortium-wanted-jose-baez-zimmerman|title='Consortium' wanted Jose Baez for Zimmerman | HLNtv.com|publisher=hlntv.com|accessdate=2014-03-22}} Zimmerman chose Mark O'Mara. Ultimately, Baez ended up representing a lead detective in the case, Chris Serino.{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/11/19/3105467/detective-in-george-zimmerman.html|title=Detective in George Zimmerman case turns to Jose Baez for legal help – Zimmerman Case – MiamiHerald.com|publisher=miamiherald.com|accessdate=2014-03-22}} ===Cyber bullying case=== In October 2013, Baez was hired to defend the 12‑year-old suspect arrested in connection with the death of 12‑year-old Rebecca Sedwick, whose mother had claimed was bullied to the point where she committed suicide by jumping to her death from a silo in a cement factory.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2013/10/23/casey-anthony-attorney-to-represent-florida-girl-in-online-bullying-case|title=Casey Anthony attorney to represent Florida girl in online bullying case | Fox News |publisher=foxnews.com |accessdate=2014-03-22 |date=2013-10-23}} The case made national news when Polk County Sheriff Grady Judd made the first arrest in the country for [[cyberbullying]], and gave interviews on all major media shows including the ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today Show]]'' and ''[[Good Morning America]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/video/today/53294590#53294590|title=Sheriff: We won't tolerate cyberbullying – Video on TODAY.com|publisher=today.com|accessdate=2014-03-22}} Baez criticized Sheriff Judd for releasing the juveniles names and photographs setting off a battle between the sheriff and defense attorney.{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/video/jose-baez-insists-12-old-224235671.html|title=Jose Baez insists 12-year-old accused bully is innocent; triggers epic battle with Sheriff Judd | Watch the video – Yahoo News|publisher=news.yahoo.com|accessdate=2014-03-22}} Sheriff Judd told the media that Baez "a flashy lawyer from out of town should go work out a plea deal." In the end, all charges against his client were dropped.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2510841/Jose-Baez-Stalking-charges-dropped-girls-drove-Rebecca-Sedwick-12-suicide.html|title=Jose Baez: Stalking charges dropped against both girls who 'drove Rebecca Sedwick, 12, to suicide' | Mail Online |publisher=dailymail.co.uk |accessdate=2014-03-22 |location=London |first1=Rachel |last1=Quigley |first2=Ryan |last2=Gorman |date=2013-11-20}} After winning the case, Baez told Sheriff Judd that "He should get a lawyer and a darn good one because he's gonna need it," indicating that his client may sue the Sheriff.{{cite web|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/11/20/21551488-charges-dropped-against-girls-in-florida-cyber-bullying-suicide-case|title=Charges dropped against girls in Florida cyber-bullying suicide case – NBC News|publisher=usnews.nbcnews.com|accessdate=2014-03-22}} No known further legal action occurred. === Aaron Hernandez 2013 murder appeal === Baez was working with [[Aaron Hernandez]] to appeal his conviction for the [[murder of Odin Lloyd]] up until Hernandez's apparent suicide on April 19, 2017.{{cite web|author=Mike DeForest |url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/jose-baez-to-represent-aaron-hernandez |title=Jose Baez to represent Aaron Hernandez |publisher=Clickorlando.com |date=2016-06-07 |accessdate=2017-04-25}} Baez has stated publicly that he does not believe that Hernandez committed suicide and is "determined to find the truth surrounding his untimely death" as "Aaron was looking forward to an opportunity for a second chance to prove his innocence." {{cite web|author=Name (required) |url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2017/04/19/jose-baez-aaron-hernandez-suicide-shock-surprise/ |title=Aaron Hernandez's Attorney 'Determined To Find The Truth' In Death « CBS Boston |publisher=Boston.cbslocal.com |date=2017-04-19 |accessdate=2017-04-25}} === Aaron Hernandez 2012 double murder charges === Baez defended Aaron Hernandez on charges related to a 2012 Boston double homicide of Daniel de Abreu and Safiro Furtado in a drive-by shooting in Boston's South End on July 16, 2012. On April 14, 2017, a jury cleared Hernandez of committing the murders.{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/04/14/sixth-day-deliberations-aaron-hernandez-double-murder-trial-start/FvbRSR9XtY1APZ5EnLnwtL/story.html |title=Jury acquits Aaron Hernandez of murder charges |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2017-04-14 |accessdate=2017-04-25}} Hernandez was already serving a life term without parole for that killing. Five days after the not guilty verdict, Hernandez committed suicide by hanging himself in his prison cell. ===Lawsuit against NFL and New England Patriots=== On September 21, 2017, Baez announced Aaron Hernandez was diagnosed with [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] by Dr. Ann McKee of [[Boston University]], and that he had filed a federal lawsuit, on behalf of Hernandez' daughter, against the [[National Football League]] and the [[New England Patriots]], seeking unspecified damages for loss of parental support. The suit alleges the league and team were aware of the dangers of repeated head injuries and refused to disclose these to Hernandez.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/21/sports/aaron-hernandez-cte-brain.html |title=Aaron Hernandez Found to Have Severe C.T.E. |first=Ken|last=Belson|publisher=The New York Times |date=2017-09-21}} ===Benjamin Shaw found Not Guilty in stabbing death=== In June 2017, Benjamin Shaw was on vacation in Shreveport LA., when he walked into a bar called the Rockin Rodeo during which time he got into a verbal altercation which was eventually taken outside to the parking lot. The unarmed victim Zacharia Casagrande was stabbed 10 times. During the trial Jose Baez was able to demonstrate that Casagrande, a military man, in a military town, was the initial aggressor and in fact was the one who attacked Benjamin Shaw. Utilizing self defense as the defense in the case. Benjamin Shaw was found not guilty.{{Cite news|url=https://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/2017/06/26/not-guilty-man-acquitted-rockin-rodeo-murder-trial/428438001/ ==See also== * [[Cheney Mason]] – co-counsel for Casey Anthony * [[Timeline of the Casey Anthony case]] * [[Linda Drane Burdick]] – lead prosecutor on the Casey Anthony case * [[Investigating Innocence]] - wrongful conviction advocacy; Baez is a founding member ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.baezlawfirm.com}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baez, Jose}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Criminal defense lawyers]] [[Category:Florida lawyers]] [[Category:Florida State University alumni]] [[Category:United States Navy sailors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Puerto Rican descent]] [[Category:Wrongful conviction advocacy]] [[Category:Writers from the Bronx]] [[Category:American legal scholars]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:Harvard Law School faculty]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = Killing an Arab | cover = Killinganarab_cov.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[The Cure]] | album = [[Boys Don't Cry (The Cure album)|Boys Don't Cry]] | released = 21 December 1978 ([[United Kingdom|UK]])
6 February 1979 (UK reissue) | format = [[Single (music)|7" single]] | recorded = 20 September 1978 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Post-punk]] | length = 2:21 | label = Small Wonder (1978)
SMALL11
[[Fiction Records]] (1979)
FICS001 | writer = The Cure ([[Robert Smith (musician)|Robert Smith]], [[Michael Dempsey]], [[Lol Tolhurst]]) | producer = Chris Parry | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[Boys Don't Cry (The Cure song)|Boys Don't Cry]] | next_year = 1979 }} "'''Killing an Arab'''" is the first single by [[The Cure]]. It was recorded at the same time as their first [[LP record|LP]] in the UK, ''[[Three Imaginary Boys]]'' (1979), but not included on the album. However, it was included on the band's first US album, ''[[Boys Don't Cry (The Cure album)|Boys Don't Cry]]'' (1980).{{cite web|last=De Muir|first=Harold|title=An Interview With Robert Smith of The Cure|url=http://www.musicfanclubs.org/cure/press/I94.html|work=Eastcoast Rocket|accessdate=27 April 2011}} This song lends two of its lines to the titles of one of The Cure's compilation albums, ''[[Standing on a Beach]]'', and to its CD/video counterpart ''[[Staring at the Sea]]''. ==Lyrics and music== Composer [[Robert Smith (musician)|Robert Smith]] has said that the song "was a short poetic attempt at condensing my impression of the key moments in ''[[The Stranger (Camus novel)|L'Étranger]]'' (''The Stranger'') by [[Albert Camus]]".''Cure News'' number 11, October 1991 The lyrics describe a shooting on a beach, in which the [[Arab]] of the title is killed by the song's narrator; in Camus' story the protagonist, Meursault, shoots an Arab on a beach, overwhelmed by his surroundings. Meursault is condemned for his honesty about his feelings. He is considered an outsider (or "stranger") because "he refuses to lie" and "doesn't play the game".Camus, Albert, ''The Outsider'', Penguin Classics, 1989, p. 118 (afterword by Albert Camus, 8 January 1955) Upon release, ''[[Melody Maker]]'' compared the song to "[[Hong Kong Garden (song)|Hong Kong Garden]]" by [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]]. Music critic Ian Birch wrote: "As 'Hong Kong Garden' used a simple Oriental-styled riff to striking effect, so '[Killing An] Arab' conjures up edginess through a Moorish-flavour guitar pattern".{{cite magazine|first= Ian |last= Birch |magazine= [[Melody Maker]] |title= Practical Poprock |date= 24 March 1979}} ==Controversial content== The track has a controversial history, since it has often been viewed as promoting violence against Arabs.{{cite web|title=The Popular Arts in America: A History of Punk Rock |isbn=9780757571176|url=}} In the US, The Cure's first compilation of singles, ''[[Standing on a Beach]]'' (1986), was packaged with a sticker advising against racist usage of the song.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/21/arts/rock-group-accedes-to-arab-protest.html | first=Jon | last=Pareles | date=21 January 1987 | accessdate=5 February 2013 | title=Rock Group Accedes to Arab Protest}} Smith and Elektra requested that radio stations discontinue airing the song and saw the sticker as a compromise to prevent having to pull the album from sale entirely. It saw controversy again during the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]] and following the [[September 11 attacks]].{{cite news | url=http://www.chartattack.com/news/2001/10/29/oh-god-not-again-robert-smith-on-killing-an-arab/ | first=Sean K. | last=Robb | publisher=''[[Chart (magazine)|Chart]]'' | date=29 October 2001 | accessdate=8 October 2009 | title='Oh God, not again': Robert Smith on Killing An Arab}} "Killing an Arab" was the only single from the ''Three Imaginary Boys'' era not to be included on that album's [[Three Imaginary Boys#2004 Deluxe Edition|2004 remaster]] although it remains available on the albums ''[[Boys Don't Cry (The Cure album)|Boys Don't Cry]]'' and ''[[Standing on a Beach]]''. The song was revived in 2005, when the band performed the song at several [[Europe]]an festivals. The lyrics, however, were changed from "Killing an Arab" to "Kissing an Arab". Smith added a whole new opening verse when the band performed it at the [[Royal Albert Hall]], [[London]] on 1 April 2006 as "Killing Another". The "killing another" lyric was also used during the 2007-2008 [[4Tour]]. The band performed the song as "Killing an Ahab" with lyrics inspired by [[Herman Melville]] on 2011's "Reflections" tour.{{Citation needed|date= December 2012}} ==Live performance== During live performances, the song is notably played with more energy making the song sound somewhat more anarchic and aggressive than originally recorded.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} ==Covers== "Killing an Arab" has been covered by [[Frodus]] on the 1995 Radiopaque compilation ''Give Me The Cure'', and again in 2004 by DJ [[Riton (musician)|Riton]]. Also, the [[Electric Hellfire Club]] copied it on their 2000 [[Cleopatra Records]] compilation ''Empathy for the Devil''. [[Santigold]] covered the song at [[Lollapalooza]]. NYC band the Reign Released a cover of it as a single in 2014 on (F.R.O.G Records) {{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/killing-an-arab-single/id897386859 |title=Killing an Arab - Single by The Reign on Apple Music |website=Itunes.apple.com |date=2014-06-01 |accessdate=2016-10-13}} The Australian band Turpentine also covered the song as a B-Side to their single "Filthy Little Pervert" in protest of the invasion of Iraq in 2003. ==Track listing== '''7" single''' #"Killing an Arab" #"[[10:15 Saturday Night]]" == Personnel == * [[Michael Dempsey]] – bass guitar * [[Robert Smith (musician)|Robert Smith]] – guitar, vocals * [[Lol Tolhurst]] – drums == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{MetroLyrics song|the-cure|killing-an-arab}} {{TheCure}} {{The Stranger (Camus novel)}} [[Category:1978 singles]] [[Category:Debut singles]] [[Category:The Cure songs]] [[Category:20th-century controversies]] [[Category:2000s controversies]] [[Category:Race-related controversies]] [[Category:Songs written by Robert Smith (musician)]] [[Category:Fiction Records singles]] [[Category:Songs written by Michael Dempsey]] [[Category:Songs written by Lol Tolhurst]] [[Category:1978 songs]] [[Category:Music based on novels]] [[Category:Obscenity controversies in music]]

revision.comment: Disambiguated: [[Bolia]] → [[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Ntomba |altname=Bolia, Lia |region=[[Lake Tumba]], [[Lake Mai-Ndombe]] |states=[[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] |speakers=100,000 Ntomba |date=1980 |speakers2=100,000 Lia (2000) |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo languages|Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4=[[Bantoid languages|Bantoid]] |fam5=[[Bantu languages|Bantu]] ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages#Zone C|Zone C]]) |fam6=[[Bangi–Ntomba languages|Bangi–Ntomba]] (C.30) |fam7=Mongo |lc1=nto|ld1=Ntomba |lc2=bli|ld2=Bolia |glotto=boli1263 |glottorefname=Bolia–Ntomba–Momngo |guthrie=C.35 }} '''Ntomba''' and '''Lia''' ([[Guthrie classification of Bantu languages|Bolia]]) are closely related [[Bantu languages]] of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], close enough to be considered dialects of a single Lia-Ntomba language.
The related [[Mongo language]] also has varieties called ''Ntomba'' or ''Ntumba''.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Languages of the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} {{Narrow Bantu languages|C-D}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Bangi-Ntomba languages]] [[Category:Languages of the Democratic Republic of the Congo]]

revision.text:
This article provides incomplete lists of various Jewish populations worldwide. Some cities with large Jewish populations may be missing from the list due to a lack of census data or other reliable sources of information. ==Major Jewish population centers worldwide== {{see also|Jewish population by country}} ===Jewish population by city=== Censuses in many countries do not record religious or ethnic background, leading to a lack of diversity on the exact numbers of Jewish population.{{Expand list|date=September 2014}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="background:#efefef;"|City ! style="background:#efefef;"|Country ! style="background:#efefef;", data-sort-type="number" |Number |- |[[New York City]]||{{USA}}||1,538,000{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishdatabank.org/content/upload/bjdb/US_Jewish_Population_2017_AJYB_DataBank_Final.pdf |title=Jewish US population 2016 |date= |accessdate=2018-10-25}} |- |[[Jerusalem]]||{{ISR}}||546,100{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/shnaton/templ_shnaton.html?num_tab=st02_14&CYear=2018 |title=הלשכה המרכזית לסטטיסטיקה - מקורות גידול האוכלוסייה, לפי צורת יישוב, קבוצת אוכלוסייה ודת - 2017

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
'''Lucille Gorham''' (January 18, 1931 - November 3, 2012) was a civil rights activist in [[Baltimore]] communities during the [[Civil Rights Movement]]. Born Lucille Alexander in [[Halifax, North Carolina]], Gorham moved to Baltimore in 1934 and resided a community in [[East Baltimore Midway, Baltimore|East Baltimore]]. She attended city public schools and later earned a [[General Educational Development|GED]], as well as studying at [[Sojourner–Douglass College|Sojourner Douglass College]]. Gorham lived a quiet life as a homemaker until 1967, when she became the president of Citizens for Fair Housing, a neighborhood association founded in response to the city's urban renewal plan. She soon led a successful community-owned and operated housing complex built on Madison Park Square between Caroline and Eden streets. She went on to become the director of the Madison Square Housing Association, director of the Middle East Community, and the leader of a neighborhood 4-H Club.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=|title=She gave the Middle East neighborhood a name and a dream|last=Strausbaugh|first=John|date=August 15, 1982|work=The Baltimore Sun|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
The [[Baltimore riot of 1968]] resulting from the [[assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.]] propelled Gorham's role in neighborhood activism. In August 1968, Gorham began to operate "Our House," clubhouse that offered services to the community including home-cooked meals, a place for local children to spend their Saturday evenings, and a spot for senior citizens to meet with friends.<ref>{{Cite news|title="'Our house' is A home for many."|last=Keidel|first=Janelee|date=June 13, 1969|work=The Sun|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Later in life, Gorham fought against the expansion of the [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]] medical complex in 2002. As a result of the expansion, Gorham was forced out of her home in the [[Middle East, Baltimore|Middle East]] neighborhood of East Baltimore and moved to a home in the [[Belair-Edison, Baltimore|Belair-Edison]] neighborhood of Northeast Baltimore. Gorham died at 81 years old from a battle with [[cancer]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/obituaries/bs-md-ob-lucille-gorham-20121107-story.html|title=Lucille Gorham, neighborhood activist|last=Sun|first=Jacques Kelly, The Baltimore|work=baltimoresun.com|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gorham, Lucille}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:African-American history]] [[Category:History of civil rights in the United States]] [[Category:Women in history]] [[Category:History of racial segregation in the United States]] [[Category:History of Baltimore]] [[Category:20th-century African-American activists]] [[Category:People from Halifax, North Carolina]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Lum v. Rice |SubmitDate=October 12 |SubmitYear=1927 |DecideDate=November 21 |DecideYear=1927 |FullName=Gong Lum, et al. v. Rice et al. |USVol=275 |USPage=78 |ParallelCitations=48 S. Ct. 91; 72 [[L. Ed.]] 172; 1927 [[U.S. LEXIS]] 256 |Prior=Trial court ordered writ of mandamus. Reversed by Supreme Court of Mississippi, 139 Miss. 760, 104 So. 105. |Subsequent=Affirmed, 139 Miss. 760. |Holding=A child of Chinese blood, born in and a citizen of the United States, is not denied the equal protection of the law by being classed by the state among the colored races who are assigned to public schools separate from those provided for the whites if equal facilities for education are afforded to both classes. |SCOTUS=1925-1930 |Majority=Taft |JoinMajority=''unanimous'' |LawsApplied=[[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|U.S. Const. amend. XIV]] |Overruled=In Part by ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]'' (1954) }} '''''Lum v. Rice''''', 275 U.S. 78 (1927), is a [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] case in which the Court held that the [[Racial segregation in the United States|exclusion on account of race]] of a child of [[Chinese ancestry]] from a [[state high school]] did not violate the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. The decision effectively approved the exclusion of [[Minority group|minority]] children from schools reserved for whites.[http://www.tolerance.org/magazine/number-25-spring-2004/feature/brown-v-board-timeline-school-integration-us] ==Background== In 1924, a nine-year-old [[Chinese-American]] named Martha Lum, daughter of Gong Lum, was prohibited from attending the [[Rosedale Consolidated High School]] of the [[Rosedale Consolidated School District]] in [[Bolivar County, Mississippi]] solely because she was of Chinese descent.Chapter 10: ''Gong Lum et al. v. Rice et al.'' (1927). In: Tong, Benson (editor). ''Asian American Children: A Historical Handbook and Guide''. [[Greenwood Publishing Group]], 2004. {{ISBN|0313330425}}, 9780313330421. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=uK6xhcu-4hAC&pg=PA182 182]. There was no school in the district maintained for Chinese students, and she was forced by compulsory attendance laws to attend school. A lower court granted the plaintiff's request of a [[writ of mandamus]] to force the members of the Board of Trustees to admit Martha Lum. Gong Lum's case was not that racial discrimination as such was illegal but that his daughter, being Chinese, had incorrectly been classified as ''[[colored]]'' by the authorities. Since the ruling went against them, the Board of Trustees became the plaintiff, and Lum was named the defendant in the case ''Rice v. Gong Lum'', which was heard in the Supreme Court of Mississippi. The [[Mississippi Supreme Court]] reversed the lower court's decision and allowed the Board of Trustees to exclude Martha Lum from the school for white children. Gong Lum appealed the state Supreme Court's ruling to the US Supreme Court. ==The Supreme Court's decision== In an opinion written by [[Chief Justice]] [[William Howard Taft]], the US Supreme Court affirmed the Mississippi supreme court's ruling and thus the position of the Board of Trustees. In the unanimous opinion, Taft held that the petitioner had not shown that there were no segregated schools accessible for the education of Martha Lum in Mississippi:
We must assume, then, that there are school districts for colored children in Bolivar county, but that no colored school is within the limits of the Rosedale consolidated high school district. This is not inconsistent with there being at a place outside of that district and in a different district, a colored school which the plaintiff Martha Lum may conveniently attend.
Taft further stated that given the accessibility of segregated schools, the question then was whether a person of Chinese ancestry, born in and a citizen of the United States, was denied equal protection of the law by being given the opportunity to attend a school that received "only children of the brown, yellow or black races." In reference to ''[[Cumming v. Richmond County Board of Education]]'', Taft concluded that the "right and power of the state to regulate the method of providing for the education of its youth at public expense is clear." Additionally, Taft pointed to a number of federal and state court decisions, most prominently ''[[Plessy v. Ferguson]]'', all of which had upheld segregation in the public sphere and particularly in the realm of public education. Accordingly, Taft concluded:
Most of the cases cited arose, it is true, over the establishment of separate schools as between white pupils and black pupils; but we cannot think that the question is any different, or that any different result can be reached, assuming the cases above cited to be rightly decided, where the issue is as between white pupils and the pupils of the yellow races. The decision is within the discretion of the state in regulating its public schools, and does not conflict with the Fourteenth Amendment.
The judgement of the Mississippi Supreme Court was affirmed. Martha Lum was not allowed to go to the school for white children. ==Subsequent developments== ''Lum'' was effectively overruled by the Court's decision in ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]'' (1954), which outlawed segregation in public schools. However, an important part of the decision still stands. The power of the state to make racial distinctions in its school system, and to determine the race of its students, has not been overturned because it was not an issue in ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]''.347 U.S. 483Rawles, Lee. (Host). (2017, May 17).''How a Chinese American Family Challenged School Segregation in 1920's Mississippi.'' ABA Journal: Modern Law Library [Audio podcast]. Retrieved from https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/aba-journal-modern-law-library/2017/05/how-a-chinese-american-family-challenged-school-segregation-in-1920s-mississippi/ == References == ==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last=Payne |first=Charles |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1984 |month= |title=Multicultural Education and Racism in American Schools |journal=Theory into Practice |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=124–131 |doi= 10.1080/00405848409543102| jstor= 1476441|publisher=Taylor & Francis }} *{{Cite book| url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/939994405|title=Water tossing boulders : how a family of Chinese immigrants led the first fight to desegregate schools in the Jim Crow South| publisher = [[Beacon Press]] |last=Adrienne|year =2016| first=Berard| isbn=9780807033531 | location=Boston | oclc=939994405}} ==External links== *{{wikisource-inline|Gong Lum v. Rice}} *{{caselaw source |case=''Lum v. Rice'', {{ussc|275|78|1927|el=no}} | courtlistener =https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/101145/gong-lum-v-rice/ |findlaw=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/cgi-bin/getcase.pl?court=us&vol=275&invol=78 |justia=http://supreme.justia.com/us/275/78/case.html }} {{US14thAmendment}} [[Category:United States school desegregation case law]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases]] [[Category:United States equal protection case law]] [[Category:1927 in United States case law]] [[Category:Education in Bolivar County, Mississippi]] [[Category:Overruled United States Supreme Court decisions]] [[Category:Anti-Chinese sentiment in the United States]] [[Category:Asian-American issues]] [[Category:Legal history of Mississippi]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases of the Taft Court]] [[Category:Education segregation in Mississippi]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
'''Mapuche medicine''' is the system of medical treatment historically used by the [[Mapuche people]] of southern Chile. It is essentially magical-religious in nature, believing disease to be caused by supernatural factors such as spells and curable by treatments based on rituals, thermal waters and herbs. Knowledge of medicinal herbs is one of the best-known elements of Mapuche medicine and is still used today.,<ref>[http://www.livingatlaschile.com/ Mapuche herbal medicine] {English} subtitles, Living Atlas Chile, retrieved December 07, 2013</ref><ref name=Algunos>{Spanish} Zúñiga S. Algunos aspectos de las costumbres y reseña del cuidado del niño entre los antiguos araucanos. Ars Médica. Revista de Estudios Médicos Humanísticos 2001; 141-150, retrieved December 5, 2013</ref> One of the most striking aspects of historical Mapuche medicine was the use of [[surgery]] as a treatment, which was developed to treat wounds and traumas suffered in the frequent battles between tribes. Fractures and dislocations of bones were treated by immobilising and covering the limbs with pastes and ointments made of medicinal herbs.<ref name="Cruz-Coke">Cruz-Coke, Ricardo. Historia de la medicina chilena. Primera edición. Santiago de Chile: Andrés Bello, 1995, retrieved December 05, 2013</ref> As in Europe, the practice of the [[bloodletting]] was also commonplace and used as a treatment for many conditions. In Mapuche culture, it was done by making small cuts with a very sharp stone called a "guincubue" to draw blood, then covering the cut with an astringent or herbal mix. Bloodletting was also used by parents on children to make them lighter, more agile and more capable of working and fighting, as it was thought that their blood was salty and heavy.<ref name="Cruz-Coke"/> Hygiene was very important in Mapuche life. They were very clean and tidy, bathing every day in nearby streams or rivers, regardless of weather conditions. The bark of the [[Quillaja saponaria|Quillaja tree]], which is very common in the local area, was used as soap (and is still used today in some commercial beauty products).<ref name=Algunos/>
==Historical context== The Mapuche people came about as the result of the mingling of two cultures: the [[Moluche people]], from what today is [[Pampas|Argentina’s Pampa]], with the indigenous inhabitants of the region between the [[Toltén River|Toltén]] and [[Bío Bío River|Bío Bío]] rivers in [[Chile]]. The Mapuche had no written language and their knowledge was transmitted orally. Most of their traditions and culture, including their medical knowledge, were documented for the first time by the European [[conquistador]]s.<ref>Latcham, E. Ricardo. La organización social y creencias religiosas de los antiguos araucanos. Publicaciones del Museo de Etnología y Antropología de Chile. Tomo III. Imprenta Cervantes, Santiago, 1924</ref>
[[File:Mapuche Machis.jpg|thumb|Mapuche Machis (1903)]]
==Different kind of healers== There were three main categories of doctors or healers in Mapuche medicine: the vileus, the ampiver and the machis.<ref name="Cruz-Coke"/>
* Vileus: :These were methodical doctors who believed that disease was caused by insects and worms. They worked to cure epidemic disease among the Mapuche which mainly arose after the arrival of the Spanish. * Ampiver: :These were empirical doctors with procedures based on observation, who used simple remedies and techniques. They knew how to take the blood pressure and make basic diagnoses. Their treatments were based mainly on the use of medicinal herbs. * Lawentuchefe: :They have great kwnoledge of healing through herbs and plants. They use this knowledge to help restore health when people suffer from different illnesses. The Lawentuchefe are not shamans and sometimes are confused with the Machi, but the Lawentuchefe do not have mystical knowledge. Their function is limited to herbalism and its applications to heal sickness. The state of the native forests have put the Lawentuchefes in a hard place because of the loss of the medical flora (lawen). This is also producing the loss of the Lawentuchefes in the communities. * [[Machi (shaman)|Machi]]: :The machi (Mapuche shaman) was a combination of a priest and a healer. Mapuche people visited the machi only after other healers had been unable to cure their condition. They had rudimentary knowledge of human anatomy and, though unable to form a diagnosis based on disparate symptoms such as vomiting, fever or cramps, they were able to treat some monosymptomatic diseases like scabies, sciatica or gout with good results. They had a deep understanding of the benefits of [[hot spring]]s and advised patients on which water source to help their illness. They successfully carried out minor surgery on fractures and small tumours and also had knowledge of medicinal plants, knowing specifically which plant, and which specific part of that plant, should be used to take best advantage of their medicinal qualities.
If a patient did not recover from any of these methods, the last resort was the performance of a magic ritual called "Machitún". Machis also served as advisors and oracles for their community.
[[File:Machitún Mapuche.jpg|thumb|Machitún Mapuche by [[Claude Gay]]]]
; Machitún If a machi had tried all conventional treatments without success a machitún ceremony would be tried, where the machi communicates with the spiritual world in order to find a diagnosis and a cure. For the machitún, the machi places a bunch of [[Lauraceae|laurel]] leaves with some [[Drimys winteri|canelo tree]] leaves in the centre in the corner of a small hut called a ruka [es:ruca |(ruca)], and prepares a goat for sacrifice there. Women sang mournful songs while the machi spread tobacco smoke through the room and got ready to sacrifice the animal. The goat’s heart was cut out and placed it in the canelo leaves, and then the machi simulated penetrating the patient’s abdomen in a search of the "magic poison". Finally, the machi played the [[cultrún]] and fell in a trance where the spirits would tell him how to treat the patient.<ref name="Cruz-Coke"/> On occasion, the three kinds of doctors would meet to solve a problem in a meeting called a "Thauman".<ref name="Cruz-Coke"/> Apart from the three kinds of doctors previously mentioned, there were two further kinds of surgeons. The cupove was a pathologist who would examine corpses to determine the disease and cause of death and the gutave was a surgeon expert at treating wounds, ulcers and many kinds of wounds.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}}
==Mapuche medicine today== There are several government programs today which aim to integrate traditional mapuche medicine with Western medicine. They look to incorporate the cultural aspects of Mapuche medicine into modern Western techniques and in this way facilitate bringing modern techniques into Mapuche communities. Examples include the "Programa de Salud Mapuche" (Mapuche Health Program) and the "Mesa Local (PROMAP)" (PROMAP Local Board). The latter aims specifically to incorporate Mapuche views on health and environmental issues into its work.<ref>[http://webhosting.redsalud.gov.cl/transparencia/public/AO057/ciudadana.html Ministerio de salud de Chile] redsalud.gov.cl , retrieved December 07, 2013</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Incubator|code= arn}} {{Commons category|Mapuche}} * [http://www.livingatlaschile.com/69-medicinal-herbs?f=1 Mapuche herbalist on livingatlaschile.com] * {{Official website|http://www.mapuche-nation.org|Mapuche International Link official website}} * [http://www.mapuche-nation.org/english/main/feature/m_nation.htm Mapuche-nation.org] * [http://www.xs4all.nl/~rehue/ Rehue Foundation in Netherland] * [http://members.aol.com/mapulink3/mapulink-3i/mapu-nation.html Mapulink website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060901183456/http://paa2005.princeton.edu/download.aspx?submissionId=50030 Mapuche Health] * [http://www.araucania.org Website of the Kingdom of Araucania and Patagonia] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130927132703/http://www.gendercentre.org.au/resources/polare-archive/archived-articles/trannie-mystics.htm Trannie Mystics]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Franco-Mauritian
Franco-Mauriciens | image = {{image array|perrow=2|width=65|height=85 | image1 = Paul Bérenger.png| caption1 = [[Paul Bérenger]] | image2 = Jean-Marie Gustave Le Clézio-press conference Dec 06th, 2008-2.jpg| caption2 = [[Jean-Marie Gustave Le Clézio]] }} |population = |languages = {{hlist| [[Mauritian creole|Creole]] | [[French language|French]] | [[English language|English]] }} |religions = [[Roman Catholicism]], Others |related = |related-c = |footnotes = }} A '''Mauritian of French origin''', as the name implies, is a [[Mauritians|Mauritian]] person whose ancestors are from [[France]]. A member of such group is usually identified as a '''Franco-Mauritian'''. ==Origins== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2016}} The first French settlers arrived in Mauritius (then [[Isle de France (Mauritius)|Isle de France]]) in 1722, after the previous attempts of settlement by the Dutch had failed, and the island had once again become abandoned. They lived and prospered on the island, ruling it until the British invasion of 1810. The French by now strongly identified with the island, and the terms of capitulation allowed the settlers to live on as a distinct francophone ethnic group for the next 158 years under British rule before Mauritius attained independence. By 1920 the French Mauritian population on the island was between 70,000 to 80,000 out of 375,000 inhabitants representing around 20% of the total population.{{Cite web |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/01/11/102736835.pdf |title=Sentimental Domain: Island of Mauritius, Scene of "Paul et Virginie," Seeks Return to French Control |date=11 January 1920 |website=New York Times |access-date=2018-08-23}} Not all Franco-Mauritians have pure French lineage, many also have British or other European ancestors that came to Mauritius and were absorbed in the Franco-Mauritian community or the ''gens de couleur'' (Coloureds). There are an estimated 15,000–20,000 Franco-Mauritians; French lineage is also found within the gens de couleur community with many having predominantly French ancestors—a further 30,000 people with considerable French bloodline. Within the Afro-Creole community, a large amount of people have some French ancestors from slavery. ==Demographic factors== Franco-Mauritians comprise 2% of the population of Mauritius and own many of the largest businesses in the country.{{cite news|title=The legacy of Indian migration to European colonies|url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21727896-century-after-india-ended-system-indentured-labour-its-diaspora-building|accessdate=2 September 2017|work=[[The Economist]]|date=2 September 2017}} Most Franco-Mauritians are Roman Catholic. ==See also== * [[J. M. G. Le Clézio]], a French author of Franco-Mauritian origins awarded the 2008 Nobel Prize in Literature. * [[Mauritian of Indian origin]] * [[Mauritian of African origin]] * [[Mauritian of Chinese origin]] * [[Mauritian Creole]] ==References== {{Mauritius topics}} {{French diaspora}} [[Category:Mauritian people of French descent| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mauritius]] [[Category:French diaspora by country|Mauritius]] {{Mauritius-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2011}} [[Image:PhonepayPlus logo.png|right|thumb|200px|PhonepayPlus Logo]] The '''Phone-paid Services Authority''' ('''PSA'''), known as '''PhonepayPlus''' until 1 November 2016,<ref name="ppp_rename">{{cite web |url=http://www.phonepayplus.org.uk/news-and-events/news/2016/july/uk-regulator-phonepayplus-to-rename-as-phone-paid-services-authority |title=UK regulator PhonepayPlus to rename as Phone-paid Services Authority |author= |work=PhonepayPlus |date=12 July 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025141559/http://www.phonepayplus.org.uk/news-and-events/news/2016/july/uk-regulator-phonepayplus-to-rename-as-phone-paid-services-authority |archivedate=2016-10-25 }}</ref> is the [[regulatory body]] for all [[Premium-rate telephone number|premium rate phone-paid services]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. These are the content, goods and services that consumers can buy by charging the cost to their phone bills and pre-pay phone accounts.<ref name="dg_067032">{{cite web |url=http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/DG_067032 |title=PhonepayPlus (formerly ICSTIS) |work= |publisher=Directgov |date=2 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20121015000000/http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Dl1/Directories/DG_067032 |archive-date=2012-10-15 }}</ref>
It was founded as the '''Independent Committee for the supervision of Standards of Telephone Information Services'''<ref name="icstis_about">{{cite web |url=http://www.icstis.org.uk/about/default.asp |title=ICSTIS - About |author= |work=ICSTIS |publisher= |date=12 August 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812142726/http://www.icstis.org.uk/about/default.asp |archivedate=2007-08-12 }}</ref> ('''ICSTIS''') at the request of three network operators ([[British Telecom]], [[Mercury Communications]], and [[Vodafone]]) as a response to public criticism of their profiting from adult premium rate content. It re-branded itself as '''PhonepayPlus''' in June 2007.<ref name="TheRegister_20070619">{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/06/19/icstis_rebrand_phonepayplus/ |title=Goodbye ICSTIS, hello PhonePayPlus |date=19 June 2007 |first=Christopher |last=Williams |access-date=2017-01-25 }}</ref>
It regulates services using a Code of Practice,<ref name="psa_cop">{{cite web |url=http://psauthority.org.uk/for-business/code-of-practice |title=Code of Practice |author= |work=Phone-paid Services Authority |publisher= |date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161211161014/http://psauthority.org.uk/for-business/code-of-practice |archivedate=2016-12-11}}</ref> approved by [[Ofcom]]. This sets out the rules with which all providers of phone-paid services must comply. Among other things, it requires clear and accurate pricing information, honest advertising and service content, and appropriate and targeted promotions. The code is updated approximately annually.
The Phone-paid Services Authority investigates complaints about phone-paid services. Where it decides that its rules have been broken, it can fine the company responsible, bar access to its services, and even bar the individual behind the company from running other services under a different company name. Investigations and adjudications are free to consumers and are supposed to be fully independent. The Phone-paid Services Authority regulates services using the following number ranges: 070, 087, 090, 091, 098 and 118, plus five-digit mobile shortcodes.<ref name="psa_ranges">{{cite web |url=http://psauthority.org.uk/-/media/Files/PSA/For-Businesses/Your-phone-paid-service/Code-of-Practice/Number-Ranges-Regulated-fact-sheet.ashx?la=en |title=Number ranges regulated by the Phone-paid Services Authority |author= |work=Phone-paid Services Authority |publisher= |date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161125160334/http://psauthority.org.uk/-/media/Files/PSA/For-Businesses/Your-phone-paid-service/Code-of-Practice/Number-Ranges-Regulated-fact-sheet.ashx?la=en |archivedate=2016-11-25}}</ref>
==Phone-paid Services Authority powers== When the Phone-paid Services Authority upholds a breach of its Code, the company responsible must immediately amend the service and/or its promotional material so that it complies with the Code. In most cases, companies found in breach of the Code will be charged to cover the cost of the investigation.
The Phone-paid Services Authority also has the power to impose the following sanctions: # formal reprimands # making companies come to the regulator for prior approval # ordering companies to pay full refunds to complainants # imposing fines # barring access to services # banning named persons from operating services
==Phone-paid Services Authority board== Chairs of the board have included: *Sir [[Louis Blom-Cooper]] QC, Lawyer *[[Brenda Dean, Baroness Dean of Thornton-le-Fylde]], Trade Unionist *Sir [[Peter North (academic)]] *Sir [[Alistair Graham]], Fmr Chair of the Committee on standards in public life
Members of the board have included: *Matti Alderson, regulator *Dr. Howard Baderman, A & E consultant *Ruth Evans *Hugh Griffiths,Telecoms veteran *Jeremy Hallsworth, Chief Executive Officer of BT agilemedia *[[Valerie Howarth, Baroness Howarth of Breckland]], Child care activist and founder of Childline *Yvonne Light, Writer & journalist *Kate Marcus, Barrister *Claire Milne, Telecoms veteran *[[Mark Stephens (solicitor)]], Lawyer, mediator and regulator *Howard Webber, Consumer champion *Paul Whiteing, regulator
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.psauthority.org.uk/ Official website]
{{Telecommunications industry in the United Kingdom}}
[[Category:Telecommunications in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Communications authorities]]

revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=November 2009}} The '''''Pipiltzin''''' (sg. pilli) were the [[nobility|noble]] [[social class]] in the [[Mexica Empire]]. They are below the ruling nobles in the civilization's social structure and above the commoners who achieved noble status due to an outstanding deed in war. These people were members of the hereditary nobility and occupied positions in the [[government]] as ambassadors and ministers, the army and the [[priesthood]]. The subclasses within the ''Pipiltzin'' were: tlahtohcapilli (a tlahtoani's son), tecpilli or teucpilli (a teucli's son), tlazohpilli (son of legitimate wife), and calpanpilli (son of a concubine).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Aztec Warfare: Imperial Expansion and Political Control|last=Hassig|first=Ross|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=1995|isbn=0806121211|location=Norman|pages=29}}</ref>
Children of the ''Pipiltzin'' were given extensive education in preparation for the role they will play in their adult life. They were sent to the ''calmecac'', which was the center for higher learning, to study the ancient wisdom as well as "elegant forms of speech, ancient hymns, poems and historical accounts, religious doctrines, the calendar, astronomy, astrology, legal precepts and the art of the government."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Cambridge History of Latin America|last=Bethell|first=Leslie|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1984|isbn=0521232236|location=Cambridge|pages=22}}</ref> The ''Pipiltzin,'' however, helped increase social stresses which attributed to internal weaknesses that led to the [[Aztec]] Empire's downfall.
== Origin == As the [[Aztecs]] began settling what would later become their homelands, an elite emerged (the ''Pipiltzin'') that claimed descent from the [[Toltecs]], the former empire of Central [[Mexico]]. The new hereditary elite unified the clans that had been the center of [[Aztec]] life and paved the way for a conquest empire. Some sources describe the ''Pipiltzin'' as the offspring of ''tlahtohqueh'' and ''teteuctin'', which were different social classes within the ruling nobility.<ref name=":0" />
The name was also where the [[Pipil people]] of western El Salvador get their name, as they are descendants of Toltec people who migrated and settle in El Salvador.
The authority and prestige of the ''Pipiltzin'' were based on the belief that they descended from the original migrant founders of the Aztecs and came from a mythical place.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Mexico: A Brief History|last=Chavez|first=Alicia|publisher=University of California Press|year=2006|isbn=0520233212|location=Berkeley|pages=23}}</ref> Due to this heritage, they enjoyed privileges such as special family dispensation, the use of privilege goods and dwellings that were appropriate to their station.<ref name=":1" />
==See also== * [[mācēhualtin|Macehualtin]], the commoners
==References== <references /> * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060711220553/http://irows.ucr.edu/cd/courses/122/b10toch17.htm]
{{Nobility by nation}}
[[Category:Aztec society]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Russians in Korea |image= |population=Total population not known |region1={{flagcountry|South Korea}} |pop1=47,451 |ref1=(2017)<ref name="official">http://www.moj.go.kr/doc_html/viewer/skin/doc.html?fn=16bee0209a4c23327b8953eb9892b778&rs=/doc_html/viewer/result/201712/</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.immigration.go.kr/HP/COM/bbs_003/ListShowData.do?strNbodCd=noti0097&strWrtNo=239&strAnsNo=A&strOrgGbnCd=104000&strRtnURL=IMM_6070&strAllOrgYn=N&strThisPage=1&strFilePath=imm/|title=Official Korean Website|access-date=2017-11-17}} </ref> |region2={{flagcountry|North Korea}} |pop2=Unknown |langs=[[Russian language|Russian]], [[Korean language|Korean]] |rels=[[Korean Orthodox Church]] |related-c=[[Russians in Japan]] }}
'''Russians in Korea''' do not form a very large population, but they have a history going back to the [[Korean Empire]]. The community of Russian subjects/citizens in [[Korea]] has historically included not just [[Russians|ethnic Russians]], but members of [[ethnic groups of Russia|minority groups of Russia]] as well, such as [[Tatars]], [[Polish minority in Russia|Poles]], and, more recently, return migrants from among the ''[[Koryo-saram]]'' ([[Korean diaspora|ethnic Koreans]] whose ancestors migrated to the [[Russian Far East]] in the late 19th century) and [[Sakhalin Koreans]].<ref name="Joongang">{{citation|date=2004-11-08|accessdate=2007-05-28|title=A taste of Russia in heart of Seoul|periodical=JoongAng Daily|url=http://english.seoul.go.kr/today/news/newsclip/1213490_3675.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612170444/http://english.seoul.go.kr/today/news/newsclip/1213490_3675.html|archivedate=2008-06-12}}</ref>
==Migration history==
===Early history=== [[File:Former Russia legation of Korea 02.JPG|thumb|left|The old Russian legation building in Seoul]] The earliest Russian subject in Korea is believed to have been [[Afanasy Ivanovich Seredin-Sabatin]] (Афанасий Иванович Середин-Сабатин), an architect from a family [[Swiss emigration to Russia|of Swiss origin]]; he was invited to Korea from [[Tianjin]], [[China]] in 1884 by [[Gojong of the Korean Empire|King Gojong]]. [[Karl Ivanovich Weber]] became the Russian Empire's official representative in Seoul in April 1885.<ref>{{harvnb|Volkov|2004}}</ref> With the establishment of formal relations, more Russians began migrating into Korea throughout the 1890s, largely via [[Manchuria]]. At that time, the community was centred on the Russian legation, opened in 1890, and the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] of [[Saint Nicholas]], opened in 1903, both located in Seoul's Jeongdong (located in present-day [[Jung-gu, Seoul|Jung-gu]]). The Russian community in these days was composed largely of missionaries, diplomats, and businessmen; Russia played an important role in the Korean politics of the era, and at one point, Gojong actually [[Korea royal refuge at the Russian legation|lived in the Russian compound]], in fear of his life after the 1895 assassination of his wife [[Empress Myeongseong|Queen Min]]. However, with Russia's defeat in the 1905 [[Russo-Japanese War]], Russian influence in Korea began to wane.<ref>{{harvnb|Clark|1994|pp=41–42}}</ref>
The 1922 influx of Russian refugees from the [[History of Vladivostok#After the Revolution|fall of Vladivostok]] to the [[Red Army]] would completely change the face of the community.<ref name="Lankov">{{citation|url=http://news.empas.com/show.tsp/cp_kt/20031008n02977/?kw=advert%20%3Cb%3E%26%3C%2Fb%3E|title=The Dawn of Modern Korea: Russian Immigrants|last=Lankov|first=Andrei|date=2003-10-08|accessdate=2007-05-25|periodical=Empas News}}</ref> In October of that year, more than 15,000 refugees landed at [[Wonsan]], [[Kangwon-do (North Korea)|Kangwon-do]]. Roughly half were quickly able to obtain onward passage to [[Shanghai]], but the refugees who had not taken valuables with them when fleeing Vladivostok were stuck in Wonsan for the winter; they relied on charitable donations and day labour for their survival. According to [[William Arthur Noble]], an [[United States|American]] [[missionary]] in Korea, no more than 20% were literate; they lived either on overcrowded ships, or in barely heated customs warehouses at the docks.<ref>{{harvnb|Clark|1994|p=43}}</ref> In the spring of 1923, the refugees began to disperse, moving on to [[Harbin]], where there was a [[Harbin Russians|significant community of Russians]], or even to overseas destinations in [[Latin America]].<ref>{{harvnb|Clark|1994|p=44}}</ref>
In February 1925, [[Japanese–Soviet relations|Japan finally recognised the Soviet Union]], and handed over the old Russian Legation building to the new Soviet ambassador. By the late 1920s, there were only around a hundred Russians living in Seoul; former nobles and officials lived in Jeongdong, while a community of Tatars lived and worked in the markets near [[Namdaemun]] and Honmachi (modern-day [[Myeongdong]]). However, due to [[Classism|class divisions]] within the community, the two groups had little interaction with each other.<ref>{{harvnb|Clark|1994|p=45}}</ref> [[George Yankovsky]], the grandson of a Polish noble exiled to [[Siberia]], also maintained a resort in [[Chongjin]] which was popular among the Russian communities of East Asia, but virtually unknown to other westerners; when the [[Soviet invasion of Manchuria|Soviets invaded North Korea]], most of the Russians still living there were arrested and forcibly repatriated to the Soviet Union.<ref>{{harvnb|Clark|1994|pp=48–52}}</ref>
===After independence from the Japanese Empire=== New Russian communities have formed in various cities in [[South Korea]]. In [[Seoul]], a "Little Russia" began to form in [[Jung-gu, Seoul|Jung-gu]]'s Gwanghui-dong, near [[Dongdaemun]], in the late 1980s. Roughly 50,000 people from [[post-Soviet states]] were estimated to live in the area in 2004, down from 70,000 several years previously due to deportations of [[illegal immigration|illegal immigrants]].<ref name="Joongang"/> In [[Busan]], Russians are concentrated in the former "Texas Town" in [[Jung-gu, Busan|Jung-gu]]'s Jungang-dong; roughly 200 are estimated to live in the city permanently, with several hundred more on short-term visas, along with a large transient population of Russian sailors.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/1999/12/01/pusan.2.t.php#|title=In Korea, 'Texas Town' Goes Russian|last=Kirk|first=Don|date=1999-12-01|accessdate=2007-05-28|periodical=International Herald Tribune}}</ref>
==Religion== [[File:Seoul St.Nicholas Cathedral.jpg|thumb|[[St. Nicholas Cathedral (Seoul)|St. Nicholas Cathedral]] in [[Seoul]], Korea]]
After the [[Korean War]] (1950-1953), South Koreans were unfavorably disposed towards Russia because of its alliance with North Korea. Korean Orthodox believers did not want to have any relations with the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. As a result, the Orthodox Community of South Korea found itself cut off from the rest of the Orthodox Church; that is the community did not belonging to any ecclesiastical jurisdiction.
This very serious ecclesiological problem was resolved as follows; On 25 December 1955, after the Christmas Divine Liturgy, the General Assembly of the Orthodox Community of South Korea unanimously decided to request to come under the jurisdiction of the [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople]]. The Ecumenical Patriarchate accepted the request and, since then, the [[Korean Orthodox Church]] has remained a metropolis of the See of Constantinople.
After the collapse of the communist regime in Russia and the Balkans in the 1990s, the first economic immigrants from Orthodox countries began to arrive in South Korea. Many of them, being strangers among strangers, were interested in finding an Orthodox church. From the beginning, they found refuge and support in the arms of the Korean Orthodox Church. The then Metropolitan [[Sotirios Trambas]] of Korea embraced them all with his love and paternal affection and slowly created the first nucleus of Slavic-speaking Orthodox faithful. He himself learned how to celebrate the Divine Liturgy in Slavonic and since 1992 in [[Seoul]] (in the chapel of the Dormition) or at the Monastery of the Transfiguration in Kapeong, where the pilgrims spent many weekend, he celebrated the Divine Liturgy for them. He also held special services for Slavic-speakers on Christmas Day and other Feast days with the old Calendar in order to give them a sense of familiarity and belonging. In 1995, during his historic first official visit to Korea, the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] [[Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople|Bartholomew]] laid the foundation stone of the chapel of Saint Maximus the Greek.
Since then the Orthodox Metropolis of Korea has undertaken the responsibility and pastoral care of all the Orthodox residing in the country as well as those who are temporary visitors and workers, such as sailors and entrepreneurs. In other words, all Orthodox believers of various nationalities (Koreans, Russians, Greeks, etc.) are “under the omophoron,” or spiritual jurisdiction and care, of the Ecumenical Patriarch. In order to provide proper pastoral care to all Orthodox in Korea, apart from the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Seoul, there is also the Chapel of St. Maximus the Greek, in which the Services and the Divine Liturgy are celebrated in Slavonic for Slavic-speakers, and occasionally in English for English speakers. Also, in the church of the Annunciation in the [[Busan]], the chapel of Saint George is used for the celebration of the Divine Liturgy in Slavonic for Slavic-speakers who reside in and near Busan.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.orthodoxkorea.org/history/|last=Zographos|first=Metropolitan Ambrosios-Aristotle|publisher=Korean Orthodox Church|date=2005-05-01|accessdate=2007-05-28|title=CHRONICLE OF THE CREATION OF ORTHODOX DIASPORA IN KOREA AND THE PASTORAL CARE OFFERED BY THE HOLY METROPOLIS OF KOREA}}</ref>
Russians in [[Pyongyang]] have sometimes been served by Orthodox clergy sent from [[Vladivostok]] since 2002.<ref>{{citation|title=Russian Orthodox Christians celebrate Pentecost in Pyongyang|date=2007-05-26|accessdate=2007-05-28|url=http://www.asianews.it/index.php?l=en&art=9377&size=A|periodical=AsiaNews.it}}</ref> The [[Church of the Life-Giving Trinity (Pyongyang)|Church of the Life-Giving Trinity]] in Pyongyang was dedicated in 2006. It was built at the order of [[Kim Jong-il]] after his visit to the church of [[Innocent of Irkutsk]] in [[Khabarovsk]].<ref>{{citation|periodical=NewsRu.com|title=Русский священник в Пхеньяне радуется за северокорейцев - жить сложно, но они истинные патриоты|date=2010-08-24|accessdate=2010-09-06|url=http://www.newsru.com/religy/24aug2010/kndr.html}}</ref>
==Notable people== {{further information|:Category:Korean people of Russian descent}} * [[Denis Laktionov]], football player * [[Andrei Lankov]], historian and journalist * [[Park No-Ja]], (formerly Vladimir Tikhonov), professor, author, columnist * [[Timofey Lapshin]], biathlon athlete * [[Valeri Sarychev]], football goalkeeper and coach * [[Ruslan Bernikov]], Hockey Player for Anyang Halla
==See also== *[[Sakhalin Koreans]] *[[Korean Orthodox Church]] *[[Immigration to South Korea]]
==References==

===Sources=== *{{citation|contribution=Vanished Exiles: The Prewar Russian Community in Korea|title=Korean Studies: New Pacific Currents|editor=Dae-Sook Suh|last=Clark|first=Donald N.|pages=41–58|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|year=1994|isbn=0-8248-1598-X}} *{{citation|issue=23|last=Volkov|first=M.|title=Русские в Корее- имена и судьбы/Russians in Korea - Names and Fates|date=May 2004|url=http://www.korusforum.org/PHP/STV.php?stid=34|journal=Korusforum Journal|publisher=Center for Contemporary Korean Studies, Russian Academy of Sciences|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090407002703/http://www.korusforum.org/PHP/STV.php?stid=34|archivedate=2009-04-07|df=}}
==Further reading== *{{citation|pages=153–160|year=2008|last=Khokhlov|first=Aleksandr Nikolaevich|issn=0131-2812|journal=Проблемы Дальнего Востока|title=Первый преподаватель русского языка в Корее Н. Н. Бирюкова: педагог, организатор военной разбедки и дипломат|url=http://elibrary.ru/item.asp?id=11567957|issue=2}} *{{citation|url=http://elibrary.ru/item.asp?id=14617769|issue=49|year=2010|pages=140–152|issn=2070-9773|last=Shkarovsky|first=Mikhail Vital'evich|title=Русская православная миссия в Корее|journal=Клио}}

page.title: Signatories to the Ladies' Petition for the Establishment of the Foundling Hospital

revision.comment: Anne, 2nd Countess of Albemarle by Sir Joshua Reynolds.jpg
revision.text:
In 1730 [[Thomas Coram]] approached aristocratic women to support the establishment of a [[Foundling Hospital]], which he would present to [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53361054|title=Thomas Coram, Gent., 1668-1751|last=Gillian.|first=Wagner,|date=2004|publisher=The Boydell Press|isbn=1843830574|location=Woodbridge, Suffolk|oclc=53361054}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/6707267|title=Coram's children : the London Foundling Hospital in the eighteenth century|last=1916-|first=McClure, Ruth K.,|date=1981|publisher=Yale University Press|year=|isbn=0300024657|location=New Haven|pages=276n30|oclc=6707267}} The women who signed were of aristocratic backgrounds, and Coram kept a list in his pocket memorandum book, captioned 'An Exact Account when each Lady of Charity Signed their Declaration'. In several cases, he had already approached the women's husbands several years earlier, and been turned away. Their involvement is widely regarded as the gateway to wider support of his philanthropic cause. In an essay in the catalogue of an exhibition celebrating women's roles in the Foundling Hospital, Elizabeth Einberg states that
Coram could see that securing the approval of a group of right-thinking women, of wives and dowagers at the pinnacle of society would highlight the Christian, virtuous and humanitarian aspects of such an endeavour and make it socially acceptable. In the events, it became not only that, but one of the most fashionable charities of the day.Elizabeth Einberg, 'Elegant Revolutionaries', article in Ladies of Quality and Distinction Catalogue, Foundling Hospital, London 2018, pp. 14-15, p.15. https://foundlingmuseum.org.uk/events/ladies-of-quality-distinction/
These female signatories are listed here in chronological order of date of their signature: {| class="wikitable" |+Signatories to the Ladies' Petition for the Establishment of the Foundling Hospital !Name !Title at the time of Signature !Date of Signature !Image |- |[[Charlotte Seymour, Duchess of Somerset|Charlotte Seymour]] |Duchess of Somerset |9 March 1729 |[[File:Charlotte Seymour, Duchess of Somerset.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Anne Vaughan, Duchess of Bolton|Ann Vaughan]] |Duchess of Bolton |22 April 1729 |[[File:Anne Vaughan.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Henrietta Paulet, Duchess of Bolton|Henrietta Needham]] |Dowager Duchess of Bolton |25 April 1729 |[[File:Henrietta_Crofts,_Duchess_of_Bolton.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Sarah Lennox, Duchess of Richmond|Sarah Lennox]] |Duchess of Richmond |22 December 1729 |[[File:Sarah_Cadogan.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Isabella Montagu, Duchess of Manchester|Isabella Montagu]] |Duchess of Manchester |6 January 1730 | |- |[[Anne Russell, Duchess of Bedford|Ann Russell]] |Duchess of Bedford |7 January 1730 |[[File:Lady_Anne_Egerton_by_Enoch_Seeman.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Elizabeth Onslow, Baroness Onslow|Elizabeth Knight]] |Baroness Onslow |6 April 1730 | |- |[[Anne Newport, Baroness Torrington|Anne Pierrepoint]] |[[Anne Pierrepont|Dowager Baroness Torrington]] |14 April 1730 |[[File:Anne Newport, Lady Torrington (nee Pierrepont).jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Frances Byron, Baroness Byron|Frances Byron]] |Baroness Byron |14 April 1730 |[[File:Frances_Lady_Byron.png|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Selina Hastings, Countess of Huntingdon|Selina Shirley]] |Countess of Huntingdon |21 April 1730 |[[File:Selina_Hastings_Countess_of_Huntington_npg_4224.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Juliana, Duchess of Leeds|Juliana Hele]] |Duchess of Leeds |24 April 1730 | |- |[[Draft:Frances, Countess of Winchilsea and Nottingham|Frances Finch]] |[[Daniel Finch, 8th Earl of Winchilsea|Countess of Winchilsea and Nottingham]] |25 April 1730 | |- |Frances Hales |Countess of Lichfield |27 April 1730 | |- |[[Dorothy Boyle, Countess of Burlington|Dorothy Boyle]] |Countess of Burlington |19 May 1730 |[[File:Michael_Dahl,_Possibly_Lady_Dorothy_Savile,_Countess_of_Burlington_and_Countess_of_Cork_(1699-1758),_circa_1720,_Hardwick_Hall,_National_Trust.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |[[Elizabeth Brudenell, Countess of Cardigan (1689-1745)|Elizabeth Brudenell]] |Countess of Cardigan |19 May 1730 |[[File:PORTRAIT_OF_LADY_ELIZABETH_BRUCE.PNG|thumb|x100px|center]] |- |Frances Thynne |Countess of Hertford |26 May 1730 | |- |Mary Tufton |Countess of Harold |6 November 1733 | |- |[[Anne van Keppel, Countess of Albemarle|Anne Lennox]] |Countess of Albermarle |6 November 1734 |[[file:Anne, 2nd Countess of Albemarle by Sir Joshua Reynolds.jpg|thumb|center|100px]] |- |[[Anne, Baroness Trevor|Anne Weldon Barnard]] |Baroness Trevor |2 December 1734 | |- |[[Anne, Baroness Ockham|Anne King]] |Dowager Baroness Ockham |21 January 1735 | |- |[[Margaret Bentinck, Duchess of Portland|Margaret Cavendish Harley]] |Duchess of Portland |7 May 1735 |[[File:Margaret_Cavendish_Bentinck.jpg|thumb|x100px|center]] |} In 2018 the [[Foundling Museum]] held an exhibition to raise awareness of the role of women in founding and running the Foundling Hospital, called ''"Ladies of Quality and Distinction"''.{{Cite web |url=https://foundlingmuseum.org.uk/events/ladies-of-quality-distinction/ |title=Ladies of Quality & Distinction Exhibition |website=[[Foundling Museum]] |language=en-GB |access-date=2018-11-17}}{{cite news |last1=Clinton |first1=Jane |title=Help find Foundling ‘mothers’ |url=http://camdennewjournal.com/article/help-find-foundling-mothers |accessdate=25 November 2018 |work=Camden New Journal |publisher=New Journal Enterprises |date=22 February 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Sanderson |first1=David |title=Race to honour first ladies of charity |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/race-to-honour-first-ladies-of-charity-3qt2vw7ft |accessdate=25 November 2018 |work=The Sunday Times |publisher=Times Newspapers Limited |date=19 February 2018 |location=London, England}} By their actions, these women succeeded She signed on 6 November 1733. == References ==
